title: 106_hr4183
content: The "Next Generation Technology Innovation Awards Act of 2000" is introduced to amend the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to establish Next-Generation Technology Innovation Awards for schools. The purpose and program authority are outlined in Section 3211 of the Act. The purpose of the "Next Generation Technology Innovation Awards Act of 2000" is to expand knowledge about advanced computers and telecommunications for teaching, address national questions about technology in education, and develop innovative technology applications aligned with academic content for widespread adoption by educational agencies. The Secretary can award grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements for up to 5 years through the Office of Educational Technology to eligible applicants for innovative technology applications aligned with academic standards. "Eligibility for grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements for innovative technology applications aligned with academic standards." To be eligible for an award under this program, a consortium must include a State or local educational agency and an institution of higher education, for-profit entity, museum, library, or other entity with relevant expertise. The application must describe the project and include a plan for independent evaluation. The Secretary may establish priorities for awards under this program, including innovative models for educational technology, projects serving multiple states, and models for underserved populations. Priority for projects serving traditionally underserved populations, including low-income students, students with disabilities, and students with limited English proficiency. Emphasis on projects with substantial financial resources, innovative models for electronic networks, and high-speed Internet access. "SEC. 3213. USES OF FUNDS." "A recipient must use funds awarded under this part to develop new educational technology applications, integrate technology across the curriculum, and implement activities to improve teachers' ability to integrate technology effectively." The recipient must use funds to develop high-quality digital content, including multimedia software, digital video, and web-based resources. This includes new technological formats for better subject understanding, computer modeling tools, new assessment methods, and distance learning options. The recipient must use funds to develop high-quality digital content, including multimedia software, digital video, web-based resources, and software supporting educational material development. This includes using telecommunications and technologies to make programs accessible to students with special needs. Promoting school-family partnerships, including parent education programs to help children achieve high academic standards and acquiring connectivity resources for distance learning. Collaborating with other technology research and development programs of the Secretary and the Federal government to accomplish project goals. The Secretary is authorized to develop tools, provide resources, offer technical assistance, conduct independent evaluations, and disseminate findings for activities funded under this part. There is also a limitation on administrative costs. The recipient of funds under this part is limited to using no more than 3 percent of the funds for administrative costs or technical assistance. The Secretary may require recipients of awards to share in the cost of activities, up to 50% of the total cost. The non-Federal share may be in cash or in-kind contributions. The Secretary can increase the share after the first year of receiving funds. The required non-Federal share will be published in the Federal Register. Authorization of appropriations is also mentioned. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal year 2001 and the following four years. Repeal of the former program for National Challenge Grants is outlined, including specific amendments to sections of the Act. The text chunk involves amendments to specific sections of the Act, including renumbering provisions and removing certain headings and authorization of appropriations language.
